paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: TRAPPIST-1 b is an Earth-sized rocky planet on a very short, likely tidally locked orbit around an M dwarf. The key question is whether it retains any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation. The study uses JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy to jointly constrain day-night heat transport and atmospheric composition.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: one rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: TRAPPIST-1 b observed with JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve, measuring thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution used as a baseline for comparison against observed thermal phase variations and spectral data.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption featuring CO2-rich composition and moderate pressure scale between 0.3-1.0 bar.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized composition atmosphere model with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing an alternative atmospheric composition scenario.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
